id_table_1.caption:
Evaluation on the DocLayNet Benchmark. A comparative analysis of outcomes on the DocLayNet Test Dataset. Here, Mask represents Mask R-CNN and Faster indicates Faster R-CNN.
In this comparison, the performances of Mask R-CNN, Faster R-CNN, and YOLOv5 are referenced from [21], and the results for the DINO model are derived from [62]. The best results are highlighted in bold.
id_table_1.table: Qh=M​L​P​(RoIAlign​(Fh,bj))subscript𝑄ℎ𝑀𝐿𝑃RoIAlignsubscript𝐹hsubscript𝑏𝑗Q_{h}=MLP(\text{RoIAlign}(F_{\text{h}},b_{j})) (1)

id_table_2.caption: Evaluation on the PubLayNet Benchmark. A comparative analysis of results on the PubLayNet Validation Set. The results highlight the effectiveness of our approach. The best results are highlighted in bold.
id_table_2.table: Qe=s​i​m​i​l​a​r​i​t​y​(Qd′,Qh′)subscript𝑄𝑒𝑠𝑖𝑚𝑖𝑙𝑎𝑟𝑖𝑡𝑦subscriptsuperscript𝑄′𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑄′ℎQ_{e}=similarity(Q^{\prime}_{d},Q^{\prime}_{h}) (2)

id_table_3.caption: Comparative Analysis of Results on the PubTables Validation Set. The best results are highlighted in bold.
id_table_3.table: Qt=Concat​(Qd,Qe)subscript𝑄𝑡Concatsubscript𝑄𝑑subscript𝑄𝑒Q_{t}=\text{Concat}(Q_{d},Q_{e}) (3)

id_table_4.caption: Detailed Ablation Analysis on the PubLayNet Validation Dataset.
id_table_4.table: o=D​e​c​o​d​e​r​(Qt,E|A)𝑜𝐷𝑒𝑐𝑜𝑑𝑒𝑟subscript𝑄𝑡conditional𝐸𝐴o=Decoder(Q_{t},E|A) (4)

id_table_5.caption: Performance comparison using various query combinations as input to the decoder on PubLayNet dataset. Here, Qdsubscript𝑄𝑑Q_{d} represents the original decoder queries, while Qesubscript𝑄𝑒Q_{e} signifies the enhanced queries. The highest mean Average Precision (mAP) is achieved by combining the original DINO queries with the enhanced queries, indicating improved performance during training with overlap in predictions. A training approach that uses Qd+Qesubscript𝑄𝑑subscript𝑄𝑒Q_{d}+Q_{e} for the initial half of training epochs before switching to Qdsubscript𝑄𝑑Q_{d} is shown to be effective.

id_table_6.caption: Performance comparison using different numbers of learnable queries to the decoder input on PubLayNet Dataset. The best-performing results are highlighted in bold, illustrating the optimal number of queries required for best model performance. As indicated, the model generally improves with more queries, up to a point, after which the performance decreases, suggesting an optimal query range for efficient detection across various object sizes.
